docs.title: Task Manager Documentation
docs.text:
Welcome to the Task Manager App documentation. This project is a fullstack web applicaton fo managing tasks efficiently.

You will find guides for Frontend and Backend develpopment, as well as setup instructions and architectural overviews.

docs.title: Quick Links
docs.text:
• GettingStarted
  • Frontend Docs
  • Backend Docs

docs.title: About Task Manager
docs.text:
Task Manager App is a fullstack web application designed to help teams manage tasks efficiently.

This project demonstrates best practices in modern web development, including:

  • React + TailwindCSS for frontend
  • GSAP for smooth animations
  • ASP.NET 9 Web API for backend
  • Entity Framework Core with PostgreSQL
  • Redis caching
  • Dockerized setup for local development

docs.title: Purpose
docs.text: The documentation is divided into Frontend and Backend sections to guide developers through both sides of the application.

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• Task CRUD (Create, Read, Update, Delete)
  • User authentication
  • Animated task interactions
  • Optimized performance with caching

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text: Follow these steps to run the project locally.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Node.js >= 18
  • .NET 9 SDK
  • Docker & Docker Compose
  • PostgreSQL or SQLite

docs.title: Setup Frontend
docs.text:
cd frontend
npm install
npm run dev

Frontend will run on http://localhost:3000.

docs.title: Setup Backend
docs.text:
cd backend
dotnet restore
dotnet run

API will run on http://localhost:5000.

docs.title: Dockerized Version
docs.text:
Run both frontend and backend together:

docker-compose up --build

The full app will be available at http://localhost:3000.

docs.title: API Overview
docs.text: The backend exposes a RESTful API for managing users and tasks. All endpoints respond in JSON format and follow consistent validation and error patterns.

docs.title: Base URL
docs.text: http://localhost:5000/swagger

docs.title: Authentication
docs.text: Authentication is handled using JWT tokens.

docs.title: Login
docs.text: POST /auth/login

docs.title: Request
docs.text:
{
  "email": "user@example.com",
  "password": "string"
}

docs.title: Response
docs.text:
{
  "token": "jwt-token-string",
  "expiresIn": 3600
}

docs.title: Body
docs.text:
{
  "email": "user@example.com",
  "password": "string"
}

docs.title: Get All Tasks
docs.text: GET /tasks

docs.title: React Frontend Overview
docs.text: The frontend is built with React 19 and TailwindCSS. It focuses on a clean component-driven architecture and performance.

docs.title: Folder Structure
docs.text: frontend/ ├── components/ # Reusable UI components ├── pages/ # Page-level components ├── hooks/ # Custom React hooks ├── context/ # React Context providers └── assets/ # Images, icons, styles

docs.title: TaskCard
docs.text: Displays individual task information and supports drag-and-drop interactions.

docs.title: TaskList
docs.text: Renders a list of TaskCards and supports filtering by status.

docs.title: NavigationBar
docs.text: Top navigation component with links to Dashboard, Profile, and Settings.

docs.title: Routing
docs.text:
• Implemented using React Router v6
  • Nested routes for Dashboard, Task Details, and User Profile

docs.title: API Integration
docs.text:
• React Query is used to fetch and cache API data
  • Handles error states and loading indicators automatically

docs.title: State Management in React
docs.text: The frontend uses a combination of React Context and React Query.

docs.title: Local State
docs.text:
• Use component-level useState for UI interactions, form values, modal open/close states
  • Keep state as close as possible to where it’s used

docs.title: Global State
docs.text:
• React Context is used for:
  • Theme (dark/light)
  • Authentication state
  • User settings
// Example: AuthContext
const AuthContext = createContext();

export const AuthProvider = ({ children }) => {
  const [user, setUser] = useState(null);

  return (
    <AuthContext.Provider value={{ user, setUser }}>
      {children}
    </AuthContext.Provider>
  );
};

docs.title: Server State
docs.text:
• React Query handles server data, caching, and background updates

  • Example: Fetching tasks

const { data: tasks, isLoading } = useQuery('tasks', fetchTasks);

docs.title: Optimization Tips
docs.text:
• Use useMemo and useCallback to prevent unnecessary re-renders
  • Split large components into smaller ones
  • Keep API requests centralized in hooks or services
